content:
“Mary Queen of Scots” thinks the answer lies in spectacles and grandiloquent addresses. “The Favourite” opts for domestic intrigues

“WOLF HALL” (2009) and “Bring Up the Bodies” (2012), Hilary Mantel’s Booker prize-winning novels, describe the vicissitudes of Henry VIII’s government. There are manoeuvrings in court, religious cataclysms in the Reformation, betrayals, weddings and beheadings. Ms Mantel made this dusty historical material fresh again by making a hero of Thomas Cromwell . She follows him from childhood to his role as right-hand-man; “The Mirror and the Light”, the final volume, will explore his downfall and execution. Using free indirect speech, and diction both rarefied and transparent, Ms Mantel gives him an inner voice which is authentic and compelling. In blending period detail with human motivations and flaws, the books demonstrated the creative possibilities offered by the past.

Two new films try to mimic this approach and look anew at female figures in British history. “Mary Queen of Scots” (pictured) is based on “My Heart is My Own” (2004), a biography by John Guy.  The film begins as Mary (Saoirse Ronan), a widow at only 18 years old, returns to Scotland from France, where she had spent her formative years. After a coup in her own country, she is exiled to England. In captivity—wearing extravagant dresses and her hair in elaborate braids—she prepares to meet Queen Elizabeth (Margot Robbie), whom she hopes will help her to reclaim the Scottish throne. But Elizabeth, without an heir and manipulated by her councillors, comes to fear that there is a larger plot afoot to make England Catholic again. “Should you murder me,” Mary spits, “remember you  murder your sister—and you murder your queen.” Hostility spills into violence.

Historians and critics have taken Beau Willimon, the screenwriter, and Josie Rourke, the director, to task over the film’s sex, violence and misleading plot (“students of Scottish history may be surprised to learn that the fate of the nation was partly decided by an act of cunnilingus,” A.O. Scott wrote in the New York Times ). Much of this is to be expected of a Hollywood period drama. The problem is that the historical embellishment distracts from the film’s aim of humanising the two monarchs, and telling a story of “a friendship that became a rivalry”. Here, the two women meet and then Elizabeth signs Mary’s death warrant: her motivations are simplified rather than interrogated. The film is visually beautiful but emotionally flat. Ms Ronan’s and Ms Robbie’s committed performances are its most redeeming features.

By contrast, “The Favourite” (pictured, above) offers an engrossing, and grotesque, portrait of Queen Anne (Olivia Colman), the last of the Stuart monarchs. By the beginning of the 18th century, her health was appalling—no other queen had ever been carried to her coronation—and gout had rendered her  periodically lame. When she is not throwing up in porcelain vases, she is consoled by a menagerie of rabbits in her bedroom and distracted by lobster races. She is attended by Sarah, the Duchess of Marlborough (Rachel Weisz), her trusted confidante who reigns by proxy.

The relationship between the two women is the driving force of the film. There are historical records of their letters, where they write in code as “Mrs Freeman” and “Mrs Morley”, but Yorgos Lanthimos, the director, adds physical intimacy and exploitation to that playfulness. Anne is dependent on Sarah, and Sarah is seeking political advancement for her family; that imbalanced arrangement works until Abigail (Emma Stone) joins the royal household as a new chambermaid. This throws things off-kilter, and Anne and Sarah’s relationship turns from affection to tolerance, and then to hatred. It is Abigail who is summoned to satisfy the Queen’s whims and sexual appetites; power is bestowed upon her instead.

“The Favourite” works because it has applied the lessons of Ms Mantel’s success. It is a domestic drama, less interested in the grand machinations of state than the petty jealousies and squabbles of its characters. Mr Lanthimos (“The Lobster”, “The Killing of a Sacred Deer”) returns to themes of safety and privilege explored in his previous work; that he intentionally adds some anachronisms—one character exclaims “what an outfit!”—hardly jars, for the viewer is focused on the people not the fidelity to the period. “Mary Queen of Scots” invites the opposite response. It has showy costumes and set pieces, but not much underneath.

那些参与活动的人们感到他们认识我，因为我的心，真实的自我，我的感恩，全都投入在这件事情上。
God created you and so He wants you to be the real you. By being authentic when you speak to God, you worship Him as your Creator.
是神创造了你，他想要你活出真正的你。你与神交谈时要作真实的你，你要敬拜神，真的把他看为你的创造者。

ex: vt. 使用；授予；放置；留宿

Make a place for them on your plate, and you’ll gain a whole new respect for the health benefits they —from lowering blood pressure to fighting belly fat.
在你的盘子上为它们留一些位置吧，你会对它们给予你的健康益处——从降低血压到消除腹部脂肪中产生全新的想法。
On his second evening in its damp, unfinished rooms, he wrote his wife, "Before I end my letter, I pray Heaven to  the best of Blessings on this House and all that shall hereafter inhabit it.
就在这潮湿、并未完工的地方第二天晚上，他就写信给他妻子，“在我写完这封信之前，我祈祷上帝能够让我尽情的享受这间房子，以及后来人也能在此定居。

ex: vt. 使全神贯注；用大字体书写；正式写成（决议等）；独占；吸引
eg2: If there was one piece of advice I would offer to improve your reading rate it would be simply to  yourself in the material you are studying.
下面有一个忠告，肯定可以提高你的阅读速度。
"Bosses shouldn't care about how employees accomplish their objectives or if they want to  themselves in MP3 players -- as long as the job gets done," he added.
只要员工们完成任务，老板们不必在意他们是如何完成的，也不用在意他们上班时是否听了MP3。
How abominable in you, then, to let me engross her horse as I did all last week!
那你上星期让我把她的马整整占用了一个星期，这有多么可恶呀！

ex: vi. 呼喊，惊叫；大声叫嚷

那就是为什么你远离开始遇到的疼痛信号后才惊叫：“哎呦”的原因。
The bus driver navigates the route, parts of which have been blocked by recent snowfalls, while the passengers gasp and , because the trail is almost too small for the bus at times.
巴士司机驾驶的路线，其中部分路段被近期的降雪堵塞了，而且因为这条小路对巴士车而言显得太窄了，游客们见此情景，有人开始紧张地喘息和惊叫。

ex: n. 执行；实施；实行；处决

eg2: He faced execution by hanging for murder.
他因谋杀罪要以绞刑处死。
Over 200 executions were carried out last year.
去年执行了 200 多起死刑。
He had failed in the execution of his duty.
他未能履行职责。
The idea was good, but the execution was poor.

Title: What makes a good period drama?

paperStatistics.title: What makes a good period drama?
paperStatistics.desc: “Mary Queen of Scots” thinks the answer lies in spectacles and grandiloquent addresses. “The Favourite” opts for domestic intrigues
